div.opener: August 19, 1930 Mr. Albert M. Greenfield Walnut and Juniper Streets Philadelphia, Pa.Dear Mr. Greenfield:
div.p: There is a matter in connection with the Women's Medical College which needs no action at the present time, but of which I think it well to inform you as you may be able to do something regarding it in the future.

You have already been somewhat in touch with the situation in reference to the buildings on N. College Avenue and no doubt with an institution of this kind, you may in the future be consulted or interested in some of its various angles. The Finance Committee consists of Mr. Sheldon P. Ritter, Miss Clara Middleton, Mr. Jay Gates, Mrs. James Starr, and myself. The Pennsylvania Company, at the present time, is fiscal agent. This is mainly due to the fact that they made a temporary loan of $100,000 secured by a mortgage upon the N. College Avenue buildings several years ago. They hold in their Trust Department endowment funds of the college and hospital amounting, at the present time, to about $800,000. They are paid $500 a year for clerical work in handling this fund, which is an inadequate payment for the work involved. With the building of the new hospital in Germantown and the growing activity of the institution, there will be more funds of various kinds to handle including a larger current bank account.

As you are probably aware, there is a very active group of people connected with this institution, who could be very useful friends of the Bankers Trust Company. They do not mean so much to the Pennsylvania Company, but they would mean a lot to us. Furthermore, if we could get the endowment funds transferred to us, it would swell our Trust fund figures considerably. It may or may not be necessary to take over the $100,000 loan. That may solve itself in the sale of the College Avenue buildings.
div.fw: BANKERS TRUST COMPANY OF PHILADELPHIA WALNUT STREET AT JUNIPER
div.p: My thought in writing to you is to give you the entire picture to keep in mind so when the occasion arises when you have any dealings with Mrs. Starr, as you no doubt will from time to time, that you can take whatever opportunity may present itself to say a good word for us along the lines suggested.
div.closer: Very truly yours, Ely J. Smith Trust Officer
